prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the person is in the wrong here. The situation is about a friend who has five kids with different fathers and is single, and the friend is constantly making hurtful comments to the person. The person finally responds by pointing out the friend's situation as a reason why she can't find a partner. The friend gets angry, and now mutual friends are criticizing the person for being privileged and not understanding.

First, I need to assess the dynamics of the friendship. The friend's comments are clearly mean and personal, targeting the person's weight, job, and dating life. The person tried to brush them off but eventually snapped. The response given was pointing out the friend's situation with multiple children by different fathers and lack of child support. The question is whether that response was justified.

On one hand, the person was defending themselves from ongoing insults. They might have felt that their friend's behavior was unfair and they were just calling out the obvious reason. On the other hand, bringing up the friend's personal issues might be seen as attacking her character, even if it's true. Friends often don't talk about such sensitive topics directly, especially if it's not the person's place to give advice.

The person's job in the adult industry is mentioned, which others might judge, but they also have an MBA and another job. The friend's comments about her work might be envious or judgmental. The person's response was honest but could come off as harsh, even if accurate. The friend might take it as an accusation, leading to her anger.

The mutual friends are saying the person is privileged, which adds another layer. The person argues they worked hard, but the friend's friends might not see her issues as valid. It's possible that both sides have valid points, but the way the person delivered the truth might have been unkind.

In terms of right or wrong, it's about whether the response was an appropriate defense or an unkind attack. Since the friend was being insulting, the person had a reason to push back, but the method might have been too direct. Maybe a better approach was to set boundaries without attacking the friend's personal life. So, while the person isn't entirely in the wrong, their response might have crossed a line. The answer might be A (they are in the wrong) because even if the truth is true, delivering it in that manner hurt the friend and caused a fallout. Alternatively, B (not in the wrong) because they were defending themselves from ongoing insults. It's a bit tricky, but in many cases, honesty without kindness can still be hurtful. So, maybe A.
